bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to R. Hart Phillips, November 5, 1952

div1.p: Hench informs Phillips about his interest in the fight against yellow fever, his discovery of the original site of Camp Lazear, and the Cuban government's plan to make Camp Lazear into a memorial park to honor all of those connected with the conquest of yellow fever. Hench requests that she make discreet inquiries to learn whether Camp Lazear will retain its name or will be called “Parque Finlay”.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to R. Hart Phillips, November 5, 1952
div1.opener:
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
November 5, 1952
Mrs. R. Hart Phillips
Havana Office
New York Times
Havana, Cuba
My dear Mrs. Phillips:
div1.p:
May I write you rather confidentially and ask you to help me with two
matters?

You have been long aware of my interest in the conquest of yellow fever
and the work of Doctor Finlay and especially of my compatriots, Major
Walter Reed and his associates. I believe you are aware of the fact that
with the help of Mr. Johnny Moran and Mr. Luis Pogolotti of Havana, I re-
discovered, in 1940, Camp Lazear which had been “lost” for forty years.
You are also aware that I have been trying ever since then to interest
the Cubans in memorializing this spot.

Several Cuban physicians have been very interested in this project. One of
them was Dr. Felipe Carbonell, another was Dr. Domingo Ramos and, more recently
Dr. Pedro Nogueira of Marianao who has stimulated the Minister of Public Health
to approve the project. Rather suddenly this spring they decided to complete
their plans to make Camp Lazear into a memorial park to honor all of those
connected with the conquest of yellow fever.

It has been my hope of course that when Camp Lazear was memorialized it would
be allowed to retain its name. Most confidentially, when I received in January
a copy of the blue prints of the project (from Doctor Nogueira), Walter Reed's
Building No. 1 was erroneously labelled “caseta de Finlay”. When I called this
to Doctor Nogueira's attention he laughed and said this was merely an error on
the part of the Cuban draftsmen who “naturally knew nothing about medical
history.” However I have received from time to time from Havana friends
clippings from Havana newspapers which have perpetuated this mistake. I have
had considerable correspondence with Doctor Nogueira this summer, trying to
help him with his plans but urging that our Cuban friends do nothing to dis-
tort historical fact or to hurt the feelings of the Americans. This is a
great opportunity for Cuban-American rapprochement and it would be most un-
fortunate if anything were allowed to spoil the affair.

I rather fear that they are going to rename Camp Lazear “Parque Finlay.” They
have already built a road, erected a wall on which certain bronze medallions
and memorial tablets will appear, put in shrubbery, erected a flag pole, etc.,
preserving Reed's Building No. 1 with some repairs. It is my personal hope
that since the Cubans have not seen fit to enclose Reed's Building No. 1, I
can raise money in this country to erect a protecting building, which building
should not be merely a static memorial but might be large enough so that it
would also comprise some sort of a unit for public service, perhaps a small
public health unit.
Mrs. R. Hart Phillips
Page 2
November 5, 1952

Now, Mrs. Phillips, you will be interested in all of this and at the ap-
propriate time will want to carry a news item about the dedication which
is now set for December 3, the date of Finlay's birthday and also “Physicians'
Day” in Havana. I understand that the Cuban Government is going to invite
officially certain Americans such as the Surgeon General or his Deputy, the
American Ambassador and so on. I have been told that I am to be invited and
will be asked to give a five or ten minute address and I plan to fly down
for the affair. But may I ask you to step out of your usual role as a
newspaper woman and help me to find out as diplomatically and discreetly as
you can, just what their plans are? I know nothing except what I have
heard from Doctor Nogueira. My own feeling is that we Americans who would
strongly wish that the name Camp Lazear be preserved may have to compromise
and accept the name “Parque Finlay.” Most certainly Doctor Finlay's name
should be first among those memorialized as it was his theory which was
proven on that spot to be correct, but no American can ever accept the re-
naming of Reed's Building No. 1 to be “Caseta de Finlay.” For the sake of
having the spot memorialized, I am not to happily willing to compromise on
the name “Parque Finlay” but it would be most unfortunate if any further
compromise were required. Also, I and other Americans are sincerely hoping
that the errors regarding the historical accuracy of Reed's Building No. 1
will be corrected in the Havana papers and be no longer perpetuated.

Here is a beautiful chance for a demonstration of Cuban-American friendship,
especially between the professions. I do hope that nothing will mar the
ceremony.

Mrs. Phillips, could you or one of your associates make discreet inquiries
from the office of the Ministry of Health (Public Relations Officer), from
Dr. Jose Raimundo Andreu, El Ministro de Salubridad y Asistencia Social, or
from Dr. Pedro Nogueira of Marianao, without involving me? I have expressed
to Doctor Nogueira my complete faith and trust in him and I do have complete
faith in him but what I don't know is how far he can get his ideas across to
his superiors. I am sure that Doctor Nogueira intends to do the right thing.

Could you perhaps say that you have noted from time to time the comments
in the Havana papers about the memorialization of Camp Lazear, that you
have heard that the dedication was to be some time soon and that you were
anxious to have the proper story for the many Americans who will be delighted
indeed to know of this gracious gesture on the part of the Cuban Government?
I am sure that if you, as a representative of the American press and as an
informant of the American medical profession, express an interest in this
project there will be every effort made to carry out the dedication in such
a way as to satisfy the pride and honor of both the Cubans and Americans.
Any information as to what you find which you can pass on to me beforehand,
I should be grateful to know. I want to keep out of sight in relation to
your activities and it would be much more effective if the inquiries came from
you, presumably without any prompting from me and of course you will approach
the matter with the idea that everything is on the up and up and that there is
no controversy involved. Then if you do find that the controversy which I have
mentioned still exists and is not being resolved, perhaps something can be
done about it, as a result of discreet inquiries on your part, or the part of
your American friends in the American embassy (whom I have not yet contacted).

Dr. Felipe Carbonell, San Lazaro 413, Havana, has long been interested in this
project. He is not, I believe, friendly with the present administration. I
am writing him, as a Cuban friend, the enclosed letter. You two are my last
hope to try to get information that all is well.
Mrs. R. Hart Phillips
Page 3
November 5, 1952

Request No. 2. On the occasion of previous visits to Havana, I have obtained
the services of a local photographer, Mr. Aldo E. Diaz, gotten for me on
several occasions by John Moran, now deceased. Mr. Diaz has gone with me
on several occasions and snapped for me many photographs, allowing me to
purchase the films to bring back home. These photographs I have used ex-
tensively to illustrate articles, make lantern slides for lectures and also
to make copies to send to the various yellow fever personalities in this
country, the surviving relatives of Reed, Lazear and so on.

I am most anxious to have again the services of Mr. Diaz or another photographer.
Mr. Diaz was particularly useful because he was always very agreeable and never
charged me too much; I think 50 or 75 cents a film. I often had him make 30
or 40 films. The last time I tried to reach him he seemed to have been on a
bender. We had trouble locating him. I think he had a couple of telephones
listed but no address. I wonder if you could help me out in this situation.
I should like to get in touch with him or, failing that, I am most anxious to
have the services of another photographer. I am anxious to have this
photographer take for me personally quite a few photographs of the actual
dedication, perhaps 20 or more. Then the next day, presumably on Thursday,
December 4, I should like to go back with him to Camp Lazear and make some
close-up photographs of the memorial, bringing the films back home, having
them developed that day if at all possible as I plan to fly back on that night,
Thursday, December 4. Once home I will at my leisure have either the Clinic
photographer or a local photographer make such prints as may be necessary to
send to the various relatives of the 25 or 30 volunteers whose names will be
memorialized.
I will certainly appreciate whatever help you can give me in this matter.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
ADDENDUM: Since dictating the above I have tried to find more precise data
concerning Mr. Diaz' address. In 1941 he was connected with Informaciones
Graficas, address Consulado 254; Telefono A-7978. However I think I last
had his services in 1948 or thereabouts, on which occasion he gave me the
enclosed card. Presumably he was no longer associated with Informaciones
Graficas but was a free lance. As I recall it, Johnny Moran and I spent a day
or two telephoning the numbers on his card, A5-2771 and A-7820. Note that no
address is given on the card. Johnny Moran, speaking Spanish, finally got
someone on the phone, found out at what address the one telephone was and then
we visited it. It was a little hole-in-the-wall somewhere down town, merely
a place where the people who owned the phone took messages for him and then
relayed them to him later. Having left word at each of these places for him
to call us, he did so the next day and we made the deal.
When I was in Cuba in January, I did not need Mr. Diaz but I did try to locate
either his name or Informaciones Graficas in the Havana directory, the white
section or the yellow section, without success. I hate very much to bother you
but since I have no address for him, I would greatly appreciate it if you would
phone these two numbers and leave word for him to call you. If he will give
you his address, I should be glad to write him or he can write me. Or on the
Mrs. R. Hart Phillips
Page 4
November 5, 1952
other hand, you can tell him what I want (he will remember me) and see if
he is willing to do it. I certainly appreciate your help.
